title: 1st Canadian Comedy Awards
text:
The 1st Canadian Comedy Awards honoured the best Canadian comedy of 1999 in live performances, television and film. The awards ceremony was presented by the Canadian Comedy Foundation for Excellence (CCFE), and was held on 6 April 2000 at the <a href="Masonic%20Temple%20%28Toronto%29">Masonic Temple</a> in <a href="Toronto">Toronto</a>, <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>. The ceremony was hosted by <a href="Dave%20Thomas%20%28actor%29">Dave Thomas</a>. A one-hour version of the ceremony was broadcast late the following night on <a href="CTV%20Television%20Network">CTV</a>, and the full program aired on <a href="The%20Comedy%20Network">The Comedy Network</a> on 9 April at 9 pm.
<a href="Canadian%20Comedy%20Awards">Canadian Comedy Awards</a>, also known as Beavers, were awarded in 23 categories. Winners were selected by members of <a href="ACTRA">ACTRA</a> (Alliance of Canadian Cinema, Television and Radio Artists), the <a href="Canadian%20Actors%27%20Equity%20Association">Canadian Actors' Equity Association</a>, the <a href="Writers%20Guild%20of%20Canada">Writers Guild of Canada</a>, and the <a href="Directors%20Guild%20of%20Canada">Directors Guild of Canada</a>. It was one of the first award presentations to use online voting. The ceremony also marked the creation of the Canadian Comedy Hall of Fame and the induction of its first honourees.
"<a href="The%20Drowsy%20Chaperone">The Drowsy Chaperone</a>" and the CBC comedy "<a href="Made%20in%20Canada%20%28TV%20series%29">Made in Canada</a>" led the way with six nominations each, followed by "<a href="Double%20Exposure%20%28comedy%20series%29">Double Exposure</a>", "<a href="Last%20Night%20%281998%20film%29">Last Night</a>", and "<a href="This%20Hour%20Has%2022%20Minutes">This Hour Has 22 Minutes</a>" with five. The big winners were "This Hour Has 22 Minutes" which won four awards in television, "The Drowsy Chaperone" which took three awards in live comedy, and <a href="Mike%20Myers">Mike Myers</a> who won three in film. <a href="Don%20McKellar">Don McKellar</a> won two awards across disciplines: best film director for "Last Night" and best playwright (together with colleagues <a href="Bob%20Martin%20%28comedian%29">Bob Martin</a>, <a href="Lisa%20Lambert">Lisa Lambert</a> and <a href="Greg%20Morrison">Greg Morrison</a>) for "The Drowsy Chaperone".
Ceremony.
The inaugural Canadian Comedy Awards ceremony was held on 6 April 2000 in <a href="Toronto">Toronto</a>, <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>. The venue was the historic <a href="Masonic%20Temple%20%28Toronto%29">Masonic Temple</a>, home of <a href="CTV%20Television%20Network">CTV</a>-affiliate <a href="The%20Comedy%20Network">The Comedy Network</a>. The ceremony was hosted by <a href="Dave%20Thomas%20%28actor%29">Dave Thomas</a>, a comedic veteran of more than 20 films and 300 sitcom episodes. Thomas is best known for the character <a href="Bob%20and%20Doug%20McKenzie">Doug McKenzie</a>, a parody of all things Canadian, and the ceremony played on similar humour by serving guests <a href="Peameal%20bacon%23Sandwiches">back bacon on a bun</a> and <a href="poutine">poutine</a>.

Broadcast.
The awards ceremony was held in Toronto's <a href="Masonic%20Temple%20%28Toronto%29">Masonic Temple</a>, which <a href="CTV%20Television%20Network">CTV Television Network</a> had equipped as a television studio in the late 1990s. The ceremony was recorded for television, produced by Higher Ground Productions and directed by <a href="Bob%20Sorger">Bob Sorger</a>. A one-hour version of the ceremony was broadcast on CTV at midnight on the night of Friday 7 April 2000, with the full program airing on <a href="The%20Comedy%20Network">The Comedy Network</a> on 9 April at 9 pm. The special was well-received by the members of the industry it represents, who awarded Sorger the Beaver for best direction of a TV special or episode in 2001.
